system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital on March 10, 2024, due to experiencing chest pain (CP) and shortness of breath (SoB). Upon evaluation in the emergency department, your initial electrocardiogram (ECG) indicated v5-6 ST elevation. Consequently, you were admitted for further evaluation and treatment of a suspected ST elevation (STEMI) myocardial infarction involving the left main coronary artery.

During your hospital stay, an ECG performed on March 11, 2024, reaffirmed the presence of v5-6 ST elevation, and you received medical therapy following the MONAC protocol, which includes morphine, oxygen, nitroglycerin, aspirin, and anticoagulants as per hospital guidelines. Your Troponin T levels, measured on the same day, showed elevated results of 30 and 29, respectively, confirming the presence of myocardial injury.

Your treatment included administration of morphine (2-4 mg as needed for pain), oxygen therapy (2-4 L/min to maintain O2 saturation above 90%), nitroglycerin (0.4 mg every 5 minutes for up to 3 doses if pain persisted), and a single dose of aspirin (324 mg, chewed).

Due to local hospital guidelines recommending percutaneous coronary intervention (PCA), efforts were made to contact the catheterization lab and the cardiology team. However, these tasks encountered delays, resulting in ongoing management with medical therapy.

By the evening of March 12, 2024, you reported a resolution of chest pain, and you requested to be discharged from the hospital. At discharge, your condition showed no recurrence of chest pain, and you appeared stable.

As part of your ongoing treatment plan, it is essential to follow up with your primary care physician for further evaluation. It is also advisable to consult with a cardiologist regarding potential further treatment options and long-term management strategies. Please ensure adherence to your prescribed medication regimen and monitor your condition closely for any recurrent symptoms.

We wish you a speedy recovery and encourage you to reach out should you experience any further symptoms or have any questions.

Sincerely,

___
